The subject of this thread has relevance since the Religious Right seems to claim some exclusivity to morality and campaigns on that. They also often end up dominating discussions on morality, which is a pity. Because of their very narrow definition of morality, the term itself seems to have acquired a negative connotation with many people - thus limiting who participates in discussions of morality. This allows the Religious Right to attach that term almost exclusively to their own views and have far too much influence in certain social agendas. 
 
 Nearly all people follow various codes of morality - even most criminals have certain codes of honor that they follow. Heck, even many higher order animal groups (chimps, etc.) have both learned and instinctual basic social codes of conduct. The question that comes up is: which one is "right"? Many religions claim that only theirs is right and, a lot of the time, the only answer that they can give is unprovable claims that :1) There is an omnipotent, all-knowing, benevolent God that passed on a metaphysically perfect version of morality.
 2) This hypothetically perfect morality was clearly passed on to mankind, who interpreted it correctly.
 3) This hypothetically perfect morality that was hypothetically correctly passed on to mankind has been unaltered by the passage of time and the politics and local morality of the ages that it passed through.These are huge and entirely unproven claims that, frankly, most of us just don't buy into. It is only a small minority of people (usually ranging in the polls on most relevant issues in the ~20% region) that follow various Christian rules strictly. Judging from answers to polls, most people who consider themselves religious stray from official dogma in a wide range of areas because they think for themselves. I suspect that the main reason that the large group of moderate religious believers are not as outspoken is that they feel uncomfortable denying the validity of parts of the Bible - a text that they also claim to honor. They forget that the Religious Right ALSO picks and chooses their moral stance by selectively quoting the Bible and conveniently ignores certain embarrassing areas of the Bible which seem to condone slavery, certainly condone stoning for adultery, etc.
 
 I, along with many if not most others, claim that there is no "right" morality or ethics but that there are trends based on human nature and psychology. For example, most human groups (religious or otherwise) have developed codes against murder, theft, and similar trends. Morality can also follow certain logical rules - as with the philosopher Kant's categorical imperitive: "Act only on the maxim through which you can at the same time will become a universal law" - meaning that we should only do those things we could rationally allow everyone else to do at the same time. For example, you cannot say that it is fine for you to not pay taxes since, if you morally allowed that nobody has to pay taxes, then our country (and thus all of us) would soon be in very desperate states.
 
 I am essentially an agnostic - though I would like to believe that there is a God, I find no evidence for His existence so I cannot claim faith in God with any confidence whatsoever. My own non-religious moral code tries to follow the basic principle of trying to treat others as I would expect to be treated (which ends up following fairly closely to Kant's formulism), as well as occasionally going out of my way to help or advocate for others based purely on empathy. 
 
 Lastly, I personally have much more respect for people who try to treat others well out of principle than for people who try to treat others well because they fear Godly or other punishment. It is the difference between the morality of a child who obeys his parents blindly, and the morality of an adult who thinks through his/her actions.
